profileText: A Representative from Michigan; born in Preston, New London County, Conn., October 2, 1804; attended the public schools, and was graduated from Trinity College, Hartford, Conn., in its first class in 1827; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Marshall, Mich., in 1833; delegate to the State constitutional convention in 1835; upon the admission of Michigan as a State into the Union was elected as a Jacksonian to the Twenty-fourth Congress and as a Democrat to the Twenty-fifth and Twenty-sixth Congresses and served from January 26, 1837, to March 3, 1841; regent of the University of Michigan 1837-1844; founded the public-school system of Michigan; member of the State board of education 1850-1852; editor of the Marshall Expounder for several years; member of the State house of representatives 1842-1846, and speaker of the house in 1846; died in Marshall, Calhoun County, Mich., on May 8, 1854; interment in Oakridge Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1836-1837 and 1915, 3 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Isaac Crary include a letter written in 1836 from Isaac Crary concerning the admission of Michigan to the Union. The papers also contain letters from 1837, to and from Benjamin Silliman, concerning the possibility of Benjamin Silliman's becoming Chancellor of University of Michigan. Also included is a letter from Edgar F. Waterman, of Trinity College, written in 1915 to Edwin C. Way concerning Isaac Crary.

recordLocation.name: Bentley Historical Library Michigan Historical Collections
